answers.answer: I'd say that it's normal for his age - children always want to test the waters, learn where the boundaries are....and then, even when they know where they are, they'll often cross them - just to see what happens when they do!  I think you're doing the right thing by acknowledging the behaviour and then asking him to stop.  I think that you need to let him know that he should be listening to you rather than openly defying you - without making it a HUGE deal, because that can sometimes make it more "fun"/like a "game".I'm sorry to hear about your son's diagnosis.  Even if he appears to be handling it well, it's still a lot for a little boy to deal with and so I wouldn't rule out that this may be behind his sudden defiance....although I'm more inclined to lean towards his age as the culprit - I do think this is normal behaviour for a boy his age.

Only other bit of information which may or may not be relevant is that he did have a transient tic about 9 months ago where he was flicking his fingers...it was usually when he was watching a movie or we were reading a book...kind of a nervous thing.  I guess that is what makes me question it???  But right now, I am trying to be calm and not make a big deal out of it whle also calmly disciplining him when he does not obey.  So confusing???

If you're really concerned, then perhaps you should speak to his pediatrician (or get a referral to one, if you haven't been already seeing one).  My oldest will be 4 in October and he goes through phases where he does things that could be considered "tics"....and then stops doing them.
Lisa, I think this may have to do with his diabetes.In children,  it causes behavior problems because of the blood sugar fluctuations.

question: My 5 yr old son was diagnosed with diabetes in late November.  He has handled it really well, no problem with testing his blood, takes one shot a day, very open about it with others...just as of 3 weeks ago, he began saying things (full sentences) and would repeat the sentence.  Usually like, "oops sorry I burped".  But he would repeat it a few seconds later whether he burped or not.  We acknowledge it and then tell him to please stop saying it.  He immediately says the phrase again after we tell him not to...he touched something I told him not to; he then walked over and looked at me and touched it again.  That to me is defiant...and the phrases, I ask him, "Why are you saying that?" and his answer is "I don't know."  He will look right at us and say the phrase again after being asked to stop.  I don't know if this is something beyond defiance or if this is normal at this age???
title: 5 yr old son, defiant, repeating phrases
